That's a great idea! Cleaning out the old grout is an essential step in preparing the area for new grout. It's important to remove as much of the old grout as possible to ensure a strong bond between the new grout and the tiles.

Remember to use a grout saw or a utility knife to scrape out the old grout, and be careful not to scratch the tiles. You can also use a wire brush or a scrub brush to remove any remaining old grout, dirt, or debris from the area.

Here are a few additional tips to keep in mind:

* Work in small sections to maintain control and avoid spreading the old grout around.
* Use a vacuum or a damp cloth to remove any debris or dust as you go.
* If you encounter any particularly stubborn areas, you can use a grout remover or a mixture of baking soda and water to help loosen the old grout.
* Be patient and take your time, as removing old grout can be a time-consuming process.

Once you've removed as much of the old grout as possible, you can move on to cleaning the area with a wire brush or scrub brush, and then apply the new grout. Remember to follow the manufacturer's instructions for mixing and applying the new grout, and take your time to ensure a smooth, even application.

If you have any more questions or need further guidance, feel free to ask. Good luck with the project!
